title: Ad-Tech Startup Innovid Bets on Display Ads
text:
As many advertising-technology companies diversify beyond serving display ads, a category that is dominated by Alphabet Inc. ’s Google, Innovid Inc. is instead making its latest bet on display.

Innovid, an ad-tech company with a focus on connected TV, has acquired display advertising firm Herolens Group LLC in an effort to round out its offerings for marketers who want to consolidate their technology relationships with fewer companies.

Innovid purchased the Buenos Aires-based firm for $30 million in equity and cash, according to people familiar with the matter. Innovid raised $30 million from Goldman Sachs Private Capital Investing in January to support its expansion. The company is preparing for a possible IPO in the next two years, it said.

The acquisition comes as ad-tech players increasingly focus on selling more video inventory on platforms like mobile and connected TV.

“Display is a bad business,” said Zvika Netter, CEO of Innovid. “This is why we stayed away from it. Everybody is gunning for TV.”

But Innovid is still interested in Herolens’s technology as more marketers consolidate ad-tech relationships and look for alternatives to Google and Amazon.com Inc., which recently agreed to acquire assets of Sizmek, including its ad server and creative ad technology, he said.

“Marketers are vetting their vendors to try to find the three-to-four really smart, good ones as opposed to having 20 or more,” said Orchid Richardson, vice president and managing director of the Interactive Advertising Bureau’s Data Center of Excellence. The trend is driven in part by marketers bringing their digital advertising and data operations in-house and looking for more efficient relationships with vendors, she said.

Herolens, founded in 2015, offers ad serving technology that helps send display ads to different websites based on user data, as well as a system that automates the creation of numerous versions of a display ad.

The acquisition isn’t about adding another business line, but about rounding out Innovid’s capabilities, Mr. Netter said.

Innovid might use data gleaned from its display ad tools—whether people see or engage with a banner ad, for example—to inform a client’s TV ad strategy, for example. Alternately, the company’s TV data insights can be used to retarget users on cheaper media, such as display ads on desktop computers or mobile.

Innovid plans to increase headcount at Herolens to about 60 employees from roughly 40, he said.
